# Diminished Chord in G# (Shape E)

The diminished chord is a unique and versatile chord in music theory. In this reference sheet, we will explore the diminished chord in the key of G# (and in the shape of E on the guitar). 

## Breakdown of Notes and Intervals

The diminished chord in G# consists of the following notes:
- G# (Root)
- B (Minor Third)
- D (Diminished Fifth)

In the shape of E on the guitar, this chord is played as follows:
- G# on the 4th fret of the low E string
- B on the 7th fret of the A string
- D on the 10th fret of the D string
- G# on the 9th fret of the G string
- B on the 10th fret of the B string
- D on the 8th fret of the high E string

## Musical Flavor and Genre

The diminished chord in G# has a tense and dissonant sound due to the diminished fifth interval in the chord. This chord is often used to create tension in music and is commonly found in jazz, classical, and some forms of metal music. It can be used to add a sense of suspense or unease to a musical piece.

## Songs Featuring the Diminished Chord in G#

Here are three songs that use the diminished chord in G#:
1. "Blackbird" by The Beatles - This song features a diminished chord in the progression, adding a touch of tension to the melancholic feel of the track.
2. "Eruption" by Van Halen - The iconic guitar solo in this song by Eddie Van Halen includes sections that make use of diminished chords for their edgy and aggressive sound.
